StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments: To achieve MERIT, student must increase the quality to meet merit requirements. Student needs to show understanding of complex information. Consider coming to office hours. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student has too much unsupported opinion. Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true by everyone should be supported with academic evidence. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student needs to improve understanding of "academic argument." Read chapter about "How to show understanding." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student should make their writing more beautiful. Read the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 3 out of 5)

OutcomeResult.FirstTryComments: Should be clearer about which languages
Unclear how chose laws relate to hiring process
Could have more details how the test works
Good that you have formal criteria but you could use it better
Good references in workshops
Need to improve presentation skills

StudentAssignment.OverallComments: Achieved all PASS and MERIT outcomes.
StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
To achieve DISTINCTION, student must increase the quality to meet distinction requirements. Writing needs focus and irrelevant information should be ignored. Any data, ideas, or theories which do not help make your point should be removed from your writing. (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) There is one correct way to format in-text citations. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great)
Slides and other visual aids are key for the audience to understand a presentation. Remember to not have too much or too little information, use more images and fewer words (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) It is important to dress professionally for presentations. Jeans, sport shoes, t-shirts, etc. are not professional. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) A presenter should never say "uh." These kinds of non-sense sounds make it more difficult for the audience to understand. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) In English we breathe more which means we pronounce the final sound more strongly. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Too much text on slides.

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
Keep up the good work but don't say "obviously"
Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) Body language is important in presentations. Do not be too stiff, use hands to gesture, and have good posture when presenting. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) Confidence is important. If a presenter is nervous, practice more and "act" confident. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) A presentation should "flow" and a presenter should never repeat words. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) English is very different in the way it is pronounced, so more practice will help you improve. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent)

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments: To achieve MERIT, student must increase the quality to meet merit requirements. Student needs to include a proper introduction. Read chapter about "How to write an introduction." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student needs to improve understanding of paragraph. Read chapter about "How to write a paragraph." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student has too much unsupported opinion. Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true by everyone should be supported with academic evidence. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student needs to improve understanding of "academic argument." Read chapter about "How to show understanding." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student should make their writing more beautiful. Read the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 2 out of 5) All evaluations should be against a good set of criteria. (your performance level: 3 out of 5)

OutcomeResult.FirstTryComments: Performance criteria should be objectively measurable
Need to develop supporting ideas more
Unprepared, question not reasonable
Always better to have accepted criteria when evaluating anything
No references at all
Need to fix formatting issues
Needs some research to achieve this

StudentAssignment.OverallComments: Achieved all PASS and MERIT outcomes.
StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
To achieve DISTINCTION, student must increase the quality to meet distinction requirements. Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true must be supported with academic evidence. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Academic argument is about using a student's own ideas and then supporting those ideas with proper evidence. For more information, students can read the chapter about "How to show understanding." (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) There is one correct way to format in-text citations. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) All references used in writing should be included on a reference list at the end of the work. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 1 out of 5 -- unacceptable) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect)
Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Presentation should be completed within time limits. Do not go too fast or too slow. (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) It was very hard to hear you when you talk softly and face away from the audience. A little louder next time.

OutcomeResult.FirstTryComments: Less definitions, more examples
Good use of narration to add analysis
Get to the point more directly
Should be more connected to meaning
Try to balance "academic" and "practical" more
Presenting with more energy would help
Need more research
Should connect more to research
More preparation would help you
Need to integrate research with your writing more
Have more books and journal articles as references
Better if answers showed more complex understanding
Need to improve referencing in writing
Need more research to achieve this
Needs some additional research to achieve this
Experiement more with unique ideas

Use larger text on slides, spell out words

StudentAssignment.OverallComments: Achieved all PASS and MERIT and DISTINCTION outcomes.
StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
Keep up the good work! There is one correct way to format in-text citations. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect)
The quality of sources used for evidence is important. Websites and anonymous writings are not good sources but books and journal articles are. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) A presentation should "flow" and a presenter should never repeat words. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) English is very different in the way it is pronounced, so more practice will help you improve. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) Ideas should be supported by proper research (avoid unsupported opinion). (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) Research should not only appear on slides, it should be integrated into what a presenter says. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more)

Interesting way to show distinction between the two points
Should have more reflection, even when your leadership was successful
More references can give you different perspectives
Great points, good references
Better critical analysis, in depth
Great integration between examples and research
Great supporting evidence
Good quantification
Need to integrate research with your writing more
Good use of research in workshops
Better if answers showed more complex understanding
Need to improve referencing in writing
Could be even more perspectives by reading more
More research in your writing would help
Try to create something crazy sometimes

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
Keep up the good work!
Slides and other visual aids are key for the audience to understand a presentation. Remember to not have too much or too little information, use more images and fewer words (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) It is important to dress professionally for presentations. Jeans, sport shoes, t-shirts, etc. are not professional. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) Body language is important in presentations. Do not be too stiff, use hands to gesture, and have good posture when presenting. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) A presentation should "flow" and a presenter should never repeat words. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) English uses tone in a different way and using only one flat tone (monotone) makes it difficult to understand a presenter. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) Boots are fun but not really professional. Watch pronunciation on "Task."

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
To achieve DISTINCTION, student must increase the quality to meet distinction requirements. There is one correct way to format in-text citations. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) All references used in writing should be included on a reference list at the end of the work. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent)
Slides and other visual aids are key for the audience to understand a presentation. Remember to not have too much or too little information, use more images and fewer words (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) It is important to dress professionally for presentations. Jeans, sport shoes, t-shirts, etc. are not professional. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) A presenter should never say "uh." These kinds of non-sense sounds make it more difficult for the audience to understand. (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Confidence is important. If a presenter is nervous, practice more and "act" confident. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Some of your text was too small, making it difficult to read.

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments: To achieve MERIT, student must increase the quality to meet merit requirements. Student needs to show understanding of complex information. Consider coming to office hours. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student has too much unsupported opinion. Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true by everyone should be supported with academic evidence. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student needs to improve understanding of "academic argument." Read chapter about "How to show understanding." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student should make their writing more beautiful. Read the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) All evaluations should be against a good set of criteria. (your performance level: 3 out of 5)

OutcomeResult.FirstTryComments: Need much more research, not just unsupported opinions
Need to develop analysis more
Test should be more researched
Always better to have accepted criteria when evaluating anything
No references at all
Need to fix formatting issues
Needs some research to achieve this

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
To achieve MERIT, student must increase the quality to meet merit requirements. Writing must be properly broken into paragraphs. For more information students can read the chapter about "How to write a paragraph." (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true must be supported with academic evidence. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Academic argument is about using a student's own ideas and then supporting those ideas with proper evidence. For more information, students can read the chapter about "How to show understanding." (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent)
Slides and other visual aids are key for the audience to understand a presentation. Remember to not have too much or too little information, use more images and fewer words (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) It is important to dress professionally for presentations. Jeans, sport shoes, t-shirts, etc. are not professional. (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Body language is important in presentations. Do not be too stiff, use hands to gesture, and have good posture when presenting. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) A presenter should never say "uh." These kinds of non-sense sounds make it more difficult for the audience to understand. (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Confidence is important. If a presenter is nervous, practice more and "act" confident. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Text was a little too small.

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments: To achieve MERIT, student must increase the quality to meet merit requirements. Student has too much unsupported opinion. Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true by everyone should be supported with academic evidence. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student needs to improve understanding of "academic argument." Read chapter about "How to show understanding." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student should understand how to only use good quality sources for evidence. Wikipedia and other anonymous writings are not ideal sources. (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student should learn how to properly use in-text citations. Read chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 3 out of 5) Student should make their writing more beautiful. Read the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 3 out of 5) All evaluations should be against a good set of criteria. (your performance level: 3 out of 5)

StudentAssignment.OverallComments: Achieved all PASS and MERIT and DISTINCTION outcomes.
StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
Keep up the good work! There is one correct way to format in-text citations. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing" (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great)
Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) Body language is important in presentations. Do not be too stiff, use hands to gesture, and have good posture when presenting. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) Confidence is important. If a presenter is nervous, practice more and "act" confident. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) A presentation should "flow" and a presenter should never repeat words. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) English is very different in the way it is pronounced, so more practice will help you improve. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great)

Good research throughout

StudentAssignment.ImprovementComments:
To achieve MERIT, student must increase the quality to meet merit requirements. All writing should include a proper introduction. More information can be found in the chapter about "How to write an introduction." (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful." (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) All evaluations should be against a good set of criteria. (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect) Ideas should be supported by proper research (avoid unsupported opinion). (your performance level: 2 out of 5 -- very weak, often incorrect)
Slides and other visual aids are key for the audience to understand a presentation. Remember to not have too much or too little information, use more images and fewer words (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) It is important to dress professionally for presentations. Jeans, sport shoes, t-shirts, etc. are not professional. (your performance level: 5 out of 5 -- Already great) When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear. (your performance level: 4 out of 5 -- Good, but can improve more) Confidence is important. If a presenter is nervous, practice more and "act" confident. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) A presentation should "flow" and a presenter should never repeat words. (your performance level: 3 out of 5 -- OK, but inconsistent) Way too much text

Outcome.Description: Explain how quality management can be measured
Evaluate the benefit of user and non-user surveys in determining customer needs
List the methods of consultation employed in one quality scheme to encourage participation by under-represented groups
Identify the value of complaint procedures and analyse how they may be used to improve quality
Report on the role of self-assessment in order to determine an organisations’s current ‘state of health’
Evaluate the importance of communicate and record keeping
Follow guidelines on the stages of staff consultation necessary for effective implementation of a quality scheme
Propose new systems or modifications to existing systems that could improve service quality
Discuss definitions of quality in terms of business and services provision
Illustrate the processes of inspection and assurance
Discuss a range of approaches to quality management
Explain the similarities and differences between the different methods
Discuss what is meant by customer satisfaction
Explain the meaning of continuous improvement
Illustrate the type of added values to be gained
Describe the types of information made available to customers and the importance given to effective marketing

Outcome.Name: M1
Outcome.Description: Participated actively in class

Outcome.Name: M2
Outcome.Description: Understanding of complex issues

Outcome.Name: M3
Outcome.Description: Appropriate structure and approach

Outcome.Name: D1
Outcome.Description: Evaluated analsysis against industry or academic sources

Outcome.Name: D2
Outcome.Description: Evidence of wide, relevant reading

Outcome.Name: D3
Outcome.Description: Innovative and creative thought

ImprovementItem.Name: Report Structure
ImprovementItem.Description: All reports need to include a proper report structures. Structure should be table of contents, executive summary (optional), intro, body, conclusion, references, appendixes.

ImprovementItem.Name: Compex information
ImprovementItem.Description: Higher grades require students to show understanding of complex information. Any student who wants help should consider meeting their teacher in their office outside of class time.

ImprovementItem.Name: Report format
ImprovementItem.Description: Business reports are writen differently from essays. For more information, read about "Difference between reports and essays"

ImprovementItem.Name: 80/20 academic evidence
ImprovementItem.Description: There should be a good balance between using student's own ideas and the ideas of others as support. For more information, students can read the chapter about "Showing Understanding" and "The 80/20 rule."

ImprovementItem.Name: Introduction
ImprovementItem.Description: All writing should include a proper introduction. More information can be found in the chapter about "How to write an introduction."

ImprovementItem.Name: Conclusion
ImprovementItem.Description: All writing should include a proper conclusion. More information can be found in the chapter about "How to write a conclusion."

ImprovementItem.Name: Improve English
ImprovementItem.Description: As a second language, you will need to continue to develop this skill (writing and speaking).

ImprovementItem.Name: Citing teacher
ImprovementItem.Description: Students should not cite their teacher when the original source is available. Citing the teacher in this case shows lack of effort on studies.

ImprovementItem.Name: Paragraphing
ImprovementItem.Description: Writing must be properly broken into paragraphs. For more information students can read the chapter about "How to write a paragraph."

ImprovementItem.Name: Cite images
ImprovementItem.Description: All images which were not created by the student must be properly cited or it counts as plagiarism.

ImprovementItem.Name: Unsupported opinion
ImprovementItem.Description: Any claim which is not commonly understood to be true must be supported with academic evidence.

ImprovementItem.Name: Academic argument
ImprovementItem.Description: Academic argument is about using a student's own ideas and then supporting those ideas with proper evidence. For more information, students can read the chapter about "How to show understanding."

ImprovementItem.Name: Attention to assessment
ImprovementItem.Description: The assignment brief must be read very carefully. Important details can be missed which can lower the grade.

ImprovementItem.Name: Writing assignment
ImprovementItem.Description: There are very basic but important details when writing any assignment.

ImprovementItem.Name: Citation 2 places
ImprovementItem.Description: Everything cited in the text must be in the references list and everything in the references list must be cited in text.

ImprovementItem.Name: Evaluate vs reporting
ImprovementItem.Description: There are differences between assessing/evaluating and reporting. More information can be found in the chapter on "Common Task Verbs"

ImprovementItem.Name: Critical vs descriptive
ImprovementItem.Description: There is a difference between descriptive analysis and critical analysis. More information can be found in chapter about "How to show understanding"

ImprovementItem.Name: Appendix
ImprovementItem.Description: There are clear rules about what goes in an appendix and how it gets referenced in the text. More information can be found in the chapter about "What to put in the appendix"

ImprovementItem.Name: Quality of sources
ImprovementItem.Description: The quality of sources used for evidence is important. Websites and anonymous writings are not good sources but books and journal articles are.

ImprovementItem.Name: Summarize
ImprovementItem.Description: Proper summarizing is something all writers must do or the text becomes too long and difficult to read.

ImprovementItem.Name: Abstract/executive summary
ImprovementItem.Description: When called for, a proper abstract/executive summary should be included. More information can be found in the chapter about Abstracts for more information.

ImprovementItem.Name: Original source
ImprovementItem.Description: The original source (original article, etc.) should be cited and students should not rely on third parties. If you cannot find the original source, ask your lecturer.

ImprovementItem.Name: Ignore irrelevant
ImprovementItem.Description: Writing needs focus and irrelevant information should be ignored. Any data, ideas, or theories which do not help make your point should be removed from your writing.

ImprovementItem.Name: Thesis
ImprovementItem.Description: Strong writing includes a thesis. The thesis is that main idea which your writing will focus on. Without a thesis, writing tends to be uninteresting and unfocused (which causes lower grades).

ImprovementItem.Name: In-text citation
ImprovementItem.Description: There is one correct way to format in-text citations. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing"

ImprovementItem.Name: Works cited
ImprovementItem.Description: All references used in writing should be included on a reference list at the end of the work. More information can be found in the chapter about "Referencing"

ImprovementItem.Name: Plagiarism
ImprovementItem.Description: Any writer who uses the work of others without proper citations is plagiarizing. In some schools plagiarism will cause a student to fail. In others, students will be removed from the school (plagiarism is stealing).

ImprovementItem.Name: Bullets/tables
ImprovementItem.Description: Proper use of bullets and tables within their text make it much easier to read. More information can be found in the chapter on "How to make your writing beautiful"

ImprovementItem.Name: Format number
ImprovementItem.Description: Numbers should be formatted like 12,345. 12345 is hard to read. 12.345678 might not mean more then 12 so make sure numbers are readable. 12,345,678,900 can often be shorted to 12.3B.

ImprovementItem.Name: More charts
ImprovementItem.Description: Charts to help communicate information (especially numerical information) better.

ImprovementItem.Name: Be more specific
ImprovementItem.Description: Being specific is important. It shows a clearer understanding. The more specific you are the more you show you understand.

ImprovementItem.Name: Beautify writing
ImprovementItem.Description: Writing is your creation and it should be beautiful. There is more information in the chapter about "How to make your writing beautiful."

ImprovementItem.Name: Read widely
ImprovementItem.Description: As a university student you are expected to read many different authors and use those perspectives in your critical analysis.

ImprovementItem.Name: Evaluation criteria
ImprovementItem.Description: All evaluations should be against a good set of criteria.

ImprovementItem.Name: Watch details
ImprovementItem.Description: Details like spelling, capitalization, and punctuation are important.

ImprovementItem.Name: Use feedback
ImprovementItem.Description: Feedback is given to help students improve. If a student ignores feedback, they will not improve.

ImprovementItem.Name: Visuals
ImprovementItem.Description: Slides and other visual aids are key for the audience to understand a presentation. Remember to not have too much or too little information, use more images and fewer words

ImprovementItem.Name: Dress
ImprovementItem.Description: It is important to dress professionally for presentations. Jeans, sport shoes, t-shirts, etc. are not professional.

ImprovementItem.Name: Eye contact
ImprovementItem.Description: Eye contact with the audience helps the audience to feel more connected to the presenter. A presenter should avoid looking at slides or looking around the room.

ImprovementItem.Name: Body language
ImprovementItem.Description: Body language is important in presentations. Do not be too stiff, use hands to gesture, and have good posture when presenting.

ImprovementItem.Name: Louder
ImprovementItem.Description: When speaking, it is important that a presenter speaks loud enough that the entire audience can hear.

ImprovementItem.Name: Uh
ImprovementItem.Description: A presenter should never say "uh." These kinds of non-sense sounds make it more difficult for the audience to understand.

ImprovementItem.Name: Confidence
ImprovementItem.Description: Confidence is important. If a presenter is nervous, practice more and "act" confident.

ImprovementItem.Name: Fluency
ImprovementItem.Description: A presentation should "flow" and a presenter should never repeat words.

ImprovementItem.Name: Clear voice
ImprovementItem.Description: It is important to speak clearly, making sure words do not slur or run together.

ImprovementItem.Name: Ending sounds
ImprovementItem.Description: In English we breathe more which means we pronounce the final sound more strongly.

ImprovementItem.Name: Grammar
ImprovementItem.Description: Grammar mistakes make it difficult to understand a presenter.

ImprovementItem.Name: Monotone
ImprovementItem.Description: English uses tone in a different way and using only one flat tone (monotone) makes it difficult to understand a presenter.

ImprovementItem.Name: Teamwork
ImprovementItem.Description: Practice together, as a team, will help a team be more unified (including transitioning from one member to the other).

ImprovementItem.Name: Timing/Pace
ImprovementItem.Description: Presentation should be completed within time limits. Do not go too fast or too slow.

ImprovementItem.Name: Pronunciation
ImprovementItem.Description: English is very different in the way it is pronounced, so more practice will help you improve.

ImprovementItem.Name: Quantity of research
ImprovementItem.Description: Ideas should be supported by proper research (avoid unsupported opinion).

ImprovementItem.Name: Research integration into answer
ImprovementItem.Description: Research should not only appear on slides, it should be integrated into what a presenter says.
